provisions.title: Prohibition Against Violating Safeguards and Privacy Rules
provisions.summary: Respondent must not violate any provision of the GLB Act's Safeguards Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 314) or Privacy Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 313), directly or through any subsidiary, division, website, or other device.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessment
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain biennial independent third-party assessments of its information security program, certifying that safeguards comply with the Safeguards Rule and adequately protect nonpublic personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, and supervisory employees within 30 days of service (current) or assumption of responsibilities (future).
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, bankruptcy, or name/address change.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 180 days after service of the order, and at other times as required, detailing how it has complied; the initial report must include the first biennial Assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: The order terminates on January 3, 2025, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging a violation of the order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Prohibition on Dissemination of Videos or Photographs Without Consent
provisions.summary: Respondent is permanently prohibited from disseminating, through a website or online service, videos or photographs exposing an individual's intimate parts unless the individual has received a clear disclosure and provided affirmative express written consent.

provisions.title: Prohibition on Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent is permanently prohibited from misrepresenting any material fact through a website or online service, including misrepresentations about data collection/use/disclosure/deletion, Respondent's own identity, and the identity of content providers or advertisers.

provisions.title: Disposition of Personal Information
provisions.summary: Respondent is permanently prohibited from using or disclosing personal information obtained in connection with the Covered Websites prior to entry of this Order, and must destroy all such personal information within 30 days of entry of this Order.

provisions.title: Amendment to Section VI – Revised Compliance Monitoring Provision
provisions.summary: Section VI of the original March 13, 2015 Final Order is amended so that John Fanning must notify the Commission for five years (running from the date of the original Final Order's issuance) whenever he discontinues his current business or employment, or affiliates with any new business or employment involving electronic commerce, social media, or the online collection or use of consumer data linked to a specific consumer, computer, or device. Notices must include the new business address, telephone number, a description of the business or employment, and his duties and responsibilities, and must be delivered by email or overnight courier to the specified FTC address.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Preservation of All Other Provisions of the Original Final Order
provisions.summary: All portions of the Commission's original Final Order issued on March 13, 2015, other than Section VI (which is replaced by the revised compliance monitoring provision above), remain in effect without any modification.

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial sworn compliance report within 60 days and submit timely notices of changes in contact information, corporate structure, or bankruptcy filings, following specified submission procedures.

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on ftc.gov and terminates twenty (20) years from issuance, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date a complaint alleging a violation is filed in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresenting Privacy Practices
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained from misrepresenting, expressly or by implication, their privacy and data security practices, including how they collect, use, transfer, and/or disclose personal information about consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. Part 1016; Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Using or Obtaining Consumer Reports
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained from using or obtaining a Consumer Report for any purpose other than a Permissible Purpose.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. provisions.title: Injunction Concerning the Provision of Privacy Notices
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained from failing to provide a Privacy Notice to each consumer with whom Defendants form a Customer Relationship or about whom Defendants make a non-excepted disclosure to a nonaffiliated third party.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. Part 1016; Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Improper Disclosure of Nonpublic Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained from disclosing Nonpublic Personal Information to nonaffiliated third parties unless the disclosure is to a Service Provider, is an Excepted Disclosure, or the consumer has been clearly informed and provided affirmative express consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. Part 1016; Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Each Covered Business must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive Information Security Program protecting the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Nonpublic Personal Information, including documentation, risk assessments, safeguards, testing, and service provider oversight.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Defendants must annually provide the Commission with a certification from a senior corporate manager or senior officer of each Covered Business attesting to compliance with the Order, the absence of uncorrected or undisclosed material noncompliance, and describing any Covered Incidents.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a report to the Commission for any Covered Business no later than ten (10) days after first notifying any government entity of a Covered Incident, including details about the incident, affected information, consumers affected, remediation steps, and copies of required notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: A civil penalty judgment of $120,000 is entered jointly and severally against Defendants, to be paid to the U.S. Treasury within 7 days of entry of this Order by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendants relinquish all rights to assets transferred under this Order; the Complaint's facts may be used as true in future proceedings; the penalty is not dischargeable in bankruptcy; and Defendants must submit their Taxpayer Identification Numbers to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. provisions.title: Prohibited Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently prohibited from misrepresenting material facts to consumers, including how Personal Information will be shared, whether they assist in obtaining loans, credit requirements, and other material aspects of products or services.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 604 and 607 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681b and 1681e; Sections 13(b) and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 53(b) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Sale, Transfer, or Disclosure of Sensitive Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently prohibited from selling, transferring, or disclosing a consumer's Sensitive Personal Information unless the consumer requested a Financial Product or Service, the disclosure is necessary for providing that service, Defendants have express informed consent, and screening requirements are met.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 604 and 607 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681b and 1681e; Sections 13(b) and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 53(b) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Required Screening of Recipients of Sensitive Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish, implement, and maintain procedures to verify the legitimate need for and monitor the use of consumers' Sensitive Personal Information by any recipient, including obtaining certifications, conducting verification, ongoing monitoring, and immediately ceasing disclosure upon indications of misuse.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 604 and 607 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681b and 1681e; Sections 13(b) and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 53(b) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently prohibited from disclosing, using, or benefitting from Personal Information obtained prior to entry of this Order in connection with lead generation activities, and must destroy such information within 30 days and instruct entities that received it to do the same.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 604 and 607 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681b and 1681e; Sections 13(b) and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 53(b) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Data Retention and Deletion
provisions.summary: Within 60 days, Respondent must document and follow a Covered Information retention schedule and provide consumers a Clear and Conspicuous link to request data access or deletion.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Multi-Factor Authentication for Users
provisions.summary: Within six months, Respondent must offer multi-factor authentication to consumer users and must not use MFA-collected information for any other purpose.

provisions.summary: Beginning one year after Order issuance and annually thereafter, a senior corporate manager or officer must certify to the FTC that Respondent has established and maintained Order requirements and is unaware of uncorrected material noncompliance.

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC has broad authority to monitor Respondent's compliance, including requesting additional reports within 10 days, directly communicating with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using undercover means without prior notice.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on ftc.gov and terminates 20 years from issuance or 20 years from the most recent federal court complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Ban on Sales to Children and Early Teens Without a Parent's Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Within six months of the Effective Date, Defendants are permanently enjoined from allowing accounts associated with Children or Early Teens to spend fiat currency or cryptocurrency in-game without first obtaining Affirmative Express Consent from a parent, following Clear and Conspicuous disclosure of key material terms.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Ban Against Sales of Chances via Covered Mechanism Without a Fiat Currency Direct Purchase Option
provisions.summary: Within six months of the Effective Date, Defendants are permanently enjoined from offering Covered Mechanism transactions without also providing consumers a direct fiat currency purchase option, presented at the same time and clearly indicating the cost.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from making express or implied misrepresentations about Covered Mechanisms, the likelihood of obtaining digital content, costs, or any other material fact concerning any Covered Product or Service.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Required Disclosures for Covered Mechanisms and Multi-Tiered Virtual Currency
provisions.summary: Within six months of the Effective Date, Defendants must clearly and conspicuously disclose odds and costs at points of sale for Covered Mechanisms, disclose virtual currency bundle details, and maintain an online notice on their website and game login screen with complete odds and cost information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning the Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from violating COPPA, including failing to post required privacy notices, failing to provide direct notice to parents, and failing to obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting, using, or disclosing children's personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Children's Personal Information Previously Collected
provisions.summary: Defendants must implement a neutral age gate within 120 days and delete personal information of users who do not provide age confirmation; suspend data activities for unidentified users after 180 days; delete all unidentified user data within one year of the Account Suspension Date; and submit sworn written statements to the Commission confirming compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Monetary Judgments
provisions.summary: A civil penalty judgment of $20,000,000 is entered jointly and severally against Defendants, payable to the U.S. Treasury within 14 days of entry of the Order by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendants relinquish all rights to assets transferred under the Order, facts in the Complaint may be taken as true in subsequent civil litigation, and Defendants must submit their Taxpayer Identification Numbers to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to key personnel within 10 days (and to new personnel before they assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from all recipients within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit a sworn compliance report one year after entry of the Order covering contact information, business details, Covered Products/Services, and compliance status; provide sworn compliance notices within 14 days of any structural or contact changes for 10 years; notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days; and submit all required materials to the Commission by email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must create specified records for 10 years after entry of the Order and retain each record for 5 years, covering accounting revenues, personnel records, consumer complaints and refund requests, and all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendants' compliance by requesting additional reports, conducting depositions and discovery, communicating directly with Defendants and their personnel, and using undercover methods, all without further leave of court.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program within 60 days covering risk assessment, safeguards, employee training, and ongoing evaluation for all Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain specified records for 10 years after issuance (retaining each for at least 5 years), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, subpoenas, representations about privacy, and records of Supplier and Sensitive Location Data Program implementation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Five-Year Prohibition Against Disclosure of Covered Driver Data to Consumer Reporting Agencies
provisions.summary: Respondents must not disclose Covered Driver Data to any Consumer Reporting Agency for five years from entry of this Order.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Limitations on Collection, Use, and Disclosure of Covered Driver Data Absent Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Within 180 days, Respondents must obtain Affirmative Express Consent from consumers before collecting, using, or disclosing their Covered Driver Data to a Third Party, with limited enumerated exceptions.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Withholding or Withdrawing Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Respondents must not limit a consumer's ability to withhold or withdraw Affirmative Express Consent for collection or use of Covered Driver Data, such as by degrading product quality or functionality as a penalty, unless data collection is technically necessary.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Data Minimization Requirement
provisions.summary: Respondents must collect no more Covered Driver Data than is reasonably necessary for the specific purpose of collection, and may only use, disclose, or retain it for that purpose.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Retention Schedule
provisions.summary: Within 180 days, Respondents must document and adhere to a data retention schedule, make it publicly available, report it to the Commission, and update it before collecting new types of Covered Driver Data.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Deletion of Prior-Retained Covered Driver Data
provisions.summary: Within 180 days, Respondents must delete or destroy all previously retained Covered Driver Data except for specified purposes, and confirm deletion in writing to the Commission. Respondents have a 90-day option to seek retroactive consent from affected consumers.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Consumer Requests to Obtain Copies of and to Delete Covered Driver Data
provisions.summary: Respondents must maintain a simple, easily-located means for U.S. consumers to request a copy of or deletion of their Covered Driver Data, and must not use information collected for such requests for any other purpose.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Deletion Request to Data Sharing Partners
provisions.summary: Respondents must request that Third Parties with whom they shared Covered Driver Data delete that data, and must not share data with any such Third Party until it confirms receipt of the deletion instructions.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Disabling Location Setting
provisions.summary: Respondents must allow consumers to disable Location Data collection from their Vehicles (where technically equipped), such as via an in-vehicle toggle, with limited exceptions for safety, theft, and legal compliance.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Declining Enrollment in OnStar
provisions.summary: Respondents must allow consumers who decline or unenroll from OnStar to disable remote data collection from their Vehicles, with limited exceptions for safety, over-the-air updates, and consumer-initiated communications.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they collect, use, disclose, or delete vehicle-linked consumer information, the purposes for such activities, or consumers' control rights over their Covered Driver Data.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Each Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies to relevant personnel on an ongoing basis for 20 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit an annual compliance report one year after issuance, provide sworn notices within 14 days of changes in contacts or corporate structure, and notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filings within 14 days.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create specified records for 20 years after issuance and retain each for 5 years, covering financial records, personnel records, consumer complaints, law enforcement communications, privacy representations, consent records, and all compliance documentation.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission may monitor compliance by requesting additional reports and records within 10 days of a written request, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondents' personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover inquiries.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is effective upon publication on ftc.gov as a final order and terminates 20 years from issuance or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.company_name: General Motors LLC, General Motors Holdings LLC, and OnStar, LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant is enjoined from making any misrepresentation in a website's privacy policy or elsewhere about the collection, use, or disclosure of personal information of a child.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Consumer Education Remedy — FTC KidzPrivacy Notice
provisions.summary: For five years, defendant must post a clear and conspicuous FTC KidzPrivacy notice (with hyperlink) in its privacy policy, in direct notices to parents, and at each location where personal information is collected on any child-directed website.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Deletion of Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant must delete all personal information collected from children through the Kids Club portion of www.jollytime.com from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry of this Consent Decree.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting to Commission
provisions.summary: Within 60 days of entry, and at such other times as the FTC requires, defendant must file a detailed written compliance report with the Commission covering its Kids Club registration process, privacy notices, parental notices, consent methods, parental review mechanisms, necessity of data collected, and data security procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Permanent Injunction Against COPPA Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Defendant, its successors, assigns, officers, agents, and employees are permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the COPPA Rule in connection with any of defendant's websites or online services.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Effect of Future Rule Amendments
provisions.summary: If the Rule is amended or modified in the future, compliance with the amended Rule will not be deemed a violation of the injunction.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Consumer Education Remedy – FTC KidzPrivacy Notice
provisions.summary: For five years, defendant must post a clear and conspicuous bold notice directing visitors to the FTC's KidzPrivacy website in its privacy policy, parental direct notices, and at each personal information collection point on its children's websites.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty Payment
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a $400,000 civil penalty within five days of entry of the Consent Decree via electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Default Interest on Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: If defendant defaults on the civil penalty payment for more than ten days, the full unpaid amount plus statutory interest becomes immediately due.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Deletion of Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Within ten days of entry, defendant must delete all personal information collected from children through its websites from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Distribution of Consent Decree to Current Personnel
provisions.summary: Within thirty days of entry, defendant must distribute copies of the Consent Decree and the FTC compliance guide to all current officers, directors, and employees with website responsibilities, obtain signed acknowledgments, and submit a compliance statement to the Commission within fifteen days thereafter.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Distribution of Consent Decree to Future Personnel
provisions.summary: For five years, defendant must provide the Consent Decree and compliance guide to future officers, directors, and employees with website responsibilities within thirty days of them assuming such roles, obtain signed acknowledgments, and maintain copies available to the FTC upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting to the FTC
provisions.summary: Within sixty days of entry, and at other times as required by the FTC, defendant must file a detailed written compliance report covering its website registration processes, privacy notices, parental consent methods, parental review procedures, necessity of data collected, and security procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping – Compliance Documents
provisions.summary: For five years, defendant must maintain print or electronic copies of documents demonstrating compliance and make them available to the FTC within fourteen days of a written request, though no document need be kept longer than two years after creation.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Notice of Business Changes
provisions.summary: For five years, defendant must notify the FTC at least thirty days before any business change that may affect its compliance obligations, including mergers, dissolutions, sales, creation or dissolution of affiliates, bankruptcy filings, or changes in corporate name or principal place of business.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Taxpayer Identification Number
provisions.summary: Defendant must furnish its taxpayer identifying number to the FTC as required by 31 U.S.C. § 7701 for purposes of collecting and reporting on any delinquent amounts.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Submission Address for Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: All reports, submissions, and notices required by Paragraphs 11–16 must be sent by certified mail to the FTC's Associate Director of Advertising Practices and to defendant's designated contact.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Continuing Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction to issue further orders for interpretation, modification, enforcement, or punishment of violations of the Consent Decree.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Ban on Sale of Customer Phone Records
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from obtaining, marketing, or selling customer phone records and consumer personal information derived from customer phone records, except as authorized by law, regulation, or lawful court order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 521 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6821

provisions.title: Prohibited Business Activities
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from making false or deceptive statements to obtain consumer personal information, and from requesting others to obtain such information unlawfully.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 521 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6821

provisions.title: Record-Keeping Provisions
provisions.summary: For eight years, Defendants must create and retain specific records for any business they majority-own or control that is engaged in obtaining, marketing, or selling consumer personal information, including accounting, personnel, customer, complaint, marketing, third-party, and order acknowledgment records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 521 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6821

provisions.title: Prohibited Business Activities
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently prohibited from materially misrepresenting verification of privacy/security protection or the frequency of such verification in connection with advertising, marketing, or sale of any product or service.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition on Data Collection Without Consent
provisions.summary: Respondent is prohibited from collecting information from Data Collection Agents unless specific disclosures are made and express affirmative consent is obtained from consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Consumer Notification and Support
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify Affected Consumers that Data Collection Agents were installed and transmitted information, and provide instructions and support for disabling/uninstalling the software.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Service of Order on Third Parties
provisions.summary: Respondent must serve Third Parties with a copy of this order before entering into or for existing contracts related to Data Collection Agents.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Data Security and Privacy
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it collects, maintains, and protects the security, privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of consumer information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards to protect personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Deletion of Collected Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must delete or destroy Collected Information in its custody or control that was collected prior to February 1, 2010.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the Commission various records, including advertisements, materials relied upon, contradictory evidence, acknowledgments, notices, and assessment-related materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Order by Personnel
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to current and future principals, officers, directors, and managers with relevant responsibilities, and secure signed acknowledgments.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Notice of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission of any change in the company that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, assignment, sale, merger, bankruptcy, or name/address changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file compliance reports with the Commission detailing how it has complied with the order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on February 20, 2033, or twenty years from the most recent date that the United States or FTC files a complaint in federal court alleging violation of the order, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Injunction Regarding Collection of Information from Children Online
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from violating COPPA requirements regarding notice to parents, verifiable parental consent, and other Rule provisions when operating websites or online services directed to children.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Deletion of Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant must delete all personal information collected from children prior to entry of this Order and is prohibited from disclosing, using, or benefitting from such information.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a civil penalty of $800,000 to the United States within 5 days of entry of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Injunction Regarding Privacy of Consumer Information
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from misrepresenting privacy practices, must disclose and obtain consent before accessing mobile device address books, and must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Third-Party Privacy Assessments
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain initial and biennial privacy assessments from qualified independent third-party professionals for twenty years.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain acknowledgments of receipt of this Order from itself, its personnel, and business entities resulting from structural changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit compliance reports and notices to the Commission at specified intervals and upon certain events.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain specified records for twenty years after entry of the Order, with each record retained for five years unless otherwise specified.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through various means including document requests, depositions, interviews, and undercover activities.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish and maintain a comprehensive information security program to protect personal information, with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it or its products maintain and protect security of Covered Device Functionality, security/privacy/confidentiality/integrity of Covered Information, or the extent to which consumers can control security of Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it uses, maintains, and protects the privacy, confidentiality, security, or integrity of covered information collected from or about consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibited Misleading Representations
provisions.summary: Defendants must not misrepresent the extent to which they collect, use, maintain, or protect the privacy, confidentiality, or security of Covered Information, or misrepresent the purpose of their collection, use, or disclosure of Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Notice and Affirmative Express Consent Provision
provisions.summary: Prior to collecting any Viewing Data, Defendants must prominently disclose what data will be collected and shared, obtain the consumer's affirmative express consent, and provide instructions for revoking consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Data Deletion
provisions.summary: Defendants must destroy Viewing Data collected prior to March 1, 2016, with certain exceptions for legal requirements or consumer consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program reasonably designed to address privacy risks and protect the privacy and confidentiality of Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Privacy Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Defendants must obtain initial and biennial privacy assessments by a qualified, independent third-party professional for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Defendants must pay $1,500,000 to the FTC and $1,000,000 to the New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs, with a portion of the New Jersey payment suspended subject to compliance conditions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendants relinquish all rights to assets transferred under this Order and acknowledge various legal and bankruptcy-related provisions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit acknowledgment of receipt of the Order and deliver copies to all relevant personnel, obtaining signed acknowledgments from recipients.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit compliance reports and notices to Plaintiffs, including an annual compliance report and notices of structural changes or bankruptcy.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create and retain specified records for 20 years, with each record retained for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, privacy representations, assessment materials, and compliance documents.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Plaintiffs have the right to monitor compliance by requesting additional reports, inspecting records, interviewing personnel, and using other lawful means including posing as consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibited Misleading Representations
provisions.summary: Defendants must not misrepresent the extent to which they collect, use, maintain, or protect Covered Information, or the purpose of their collection, use, or disclosure of Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Notice and Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Before collecting any Viewing Data, Defendants must provide prominent disclosures about data collection practices, obtain affirmative express consent, and provide instructions for revoking consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Data Deletion
provisions.summary: Within 120 days of the Order, Defendants must destroy Viewing Data collected prior to March 1, 2016, with limited exceptions for government requests, legal requirements, or user consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written privacy program designed to address privacy risks and protect Covered Information, including designated personnel, risk assessments, controls, service provider oversight, and ongoing evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Privacy Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Defendants must obtain initial and biennial third-party privacy assessments by a qualified independent professional approved by the FTC, covering specific content requirements, and must provide or retain assessments per specified timelines.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Defendants must pay $1,500,000 to the FTC and $1,000,000 to the New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs, with $700,000 due immediately and $300,000 suspended for 5 years conditioned on compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendants relinquish all rights to transferred assets, acknowledge that Complaint facts may be used in future enforcement proceedings, and confirm their Taxpayer Identification Numbers may be used for delinquency reporting.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to principals, employees, and agents within specified timeframes, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit an annual compliance report one year after issuance, provide sworn notices within 14 days of certain changes or bankruptcy filings, and follow specified submission procedures for both the FTC and New Jersey authorities.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create and retain specified records for 20 years after the Order issuance date, retaining each for at least 5 years, covering accounting, personnel, consumer complaints, representations, assessment materials, and all compliance documents.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Plaintiffs may monitor Defendants' compliance by requesting additional reports and records, communicating directly with and interviewing Defendants' affiliates, and using other lawful investigative means including undercover contact.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained and enjoined from failing to provide parental notice, failing to post a prominent privacy notice link, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent, and from violating the COPPA Rule.

provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from disclosing, using, or benefiting from children's personal information obtained prior to entry of this Order, and must destroy all such information within ten days of entry.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. provisions.title: Reopening of Matter
provisions.summary: The Commission orders the matter reopened pursuant to Section 5(b) of the FTC Act and the Commission's Rules of Practice.

provisions.title: Modification of 'Tracking Application' Definition
provisions.summary: The definition of 'Tracking Application' in the original 2009 Order (Docket No. C-4264) is revised to exclude software that monitors, records, or transmits only: (a) its own configuration, (b) information about whether it is functioning as represented, or (c) information about consumers' use of the program or application itself.

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning the Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained and enjoined from violating the COPPA Rule, including failing to provide direct notice to parents, failing to post a privacy policy link, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent, failing to delete children's personal information upon parental request, and retaining personal information longer than necessary.

provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a), and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a), and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)
