provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Within 90 days of entry and for 20 years thereafter, Defendants must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive privacy program to protect Alexa App Geolocation Information, including documentation, risk assessment, safeguards, training, access controls, and vendor oversight.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Prohibited Representations: Weight-Loss and Efficacy Claims
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from making any unsubstantiated weight-loss or efficacy claims about Covered Products unless supported by competent and reliable scientific evidence consisting of qualifying human clinical testing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibited Representations: Other Health-Related Claims
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from making any unsubstantiated representations about the health benefits, performance, or efficacy of any Covered Product beyond the weight-loss claims covered in Section I.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibited Representations: Tests, Studies, or Other Research
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting that any good or service's performance is scientifically proven, or misrepresenting the existence, contents, validity, results, or conclusions of any test, study, or research.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: FDA Approved Claims
provisions.summary: Nothing in this Order prohibits Defendants from making representations that are specifically approved or authorized in FDA labeling for Drugs or other products under applicable federal regulations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibitions on Review-Limiting Contract Provisions and Threats About Customer Communications
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from using non-disparagement contract terms, threatening customers about negative reviews, representing customers owe higher prices for speaking out, and retaliating against anyone who cooperates with law enforcement.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Deceptive Format in Advertising
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting that any website (including Gastricbypass.me) or other publication is an independent, objective resource for research or scientific information related to any good or service.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibitions Concerning Endorsements
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting endorser opinions or expertise, misrepresenting that endorsers are health professionals, and failing to clearly and conspicuously disclose material connections between endorsers and Defendants.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibited Representations: Information Privacy
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting the extent to which they maintain the confidentiality of consumer information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment
provisions.summary: A judgment of $25,246,000 is entered jointly and severally against the Corporate Defendants and Individual Defendant Don Juravin for equitable monetary relief, with specific asset transfer requirements and directions for use of collected funds.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide sufficient customer information to the FTC to facilitate consumer redress within 14 days of any written request, and are prohibited from disclosing, using, or benefitting from customer information obtained prior to entry of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.summary: Defendants must secure and preserve all underlying data and documents associated with any human clinical test or study upon which they rely to substantiate any claim covered by this Order, and must establish written procedures to protect participant information confidentiality.

provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they maintain and protect the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers in connection with online advertising, marketing, or sales.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to their size, complexity, and the sensitivity of personal information collected.

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain biannual assessments from a qualified, independent third-party professional certifying that their security program is operating with sufficient effectiveness to protect personal information.

provisions.title: Order Distribution and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondents must deliver a copy of the order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, and employees with managerial responsibilities relating to the subject matter of the order.

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification
provisions.summary: Respondents must notify the FTC at least thirty days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under the order, including dissolution, sale, merger, bankruptcy, or name/address change.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must file an initial written compliance report with the FTC within 120 days after service of the order, and at such other times as the Commission may require.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Duration
provisions.summary: The order terminates on July 30, 2023, or twenty years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging a violation of the order in federal court, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Each respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program reasonably designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected through LexisNexis products and services.
provisions.company_name: Reed Elsevier Inc. and Seisint, Inc.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to its size, complexity, and the sensitivity of personal information collected.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C § 45(a)

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to its size and the sensitivity of personal information it handles.

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Corporate respondent and any business entity controlled by Individual respondent that collects, maintains, or stores personal information must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program, documented in writing, with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681 et seq.; and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681 et seq.; and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title V, Subtitle A of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6809

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it maintains and protects the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of any covered information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available for inspection various documents related to compliance with the order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to current and future subsidiaries, principals, officers, directors, and managers with relevant responsibilities and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any corporate changes that may affect compliance obligations under this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a compliance report with the Commission setting forth in detail the manner and form of its compliance with this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on August 13, 2034, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it maintains and protects the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of any covered information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent the extent to which they use, maintain, and protect the privacy, confidentiality, security, or integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish and maintain a comprehensive information security program that is reasonably designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Third-Party Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial assessments from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional covering a 20-year period after service of the order.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must maintain and make available to the FTC for inspection all materials related to Assessments for three years and other compliance documents for five years.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Distribution and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondents must deliver copies of the order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities, and secure signed acknowledgments of receipt.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Individual Respondents' Notification Obligations
provisions.summary: Individual respondents Prasad and Srivastava must notify the Commissionwithin 10 days of changes to their residence, employment status, business ownership, or name for a period of 10 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification
provisions.summary: Respondents must notify the Commission at least 30 days prior to any change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, sale, bankruptcy, or change in corporate name or address.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must file a written compliance report with the Commission within 60 days after service of the order and submit additional reports upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on August 14, 2034, or twenty years from the most recent date that the United States or the FTC files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibition against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which it uses, maintains, and protects the privacy and confidentiality of any covered information, including whether covered information will be made publicly available.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Notice and Affirmative Express Consent Provision
provisions.summary: Before making any consumer's covered information publicly available, Respondent must clearly and conspicuously disclose this fact to the consumer and obtain their affirmative express consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Disposition of Healthcare Provider Review Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must not publicly display or maintain any healthcare provider review information (except for retrieval by its healthcare provider customers or as required by law), and must submit a sworn written statement to the Commission confirming compliance within 60 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Acknowledgements of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of this Order within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to key personnel and new hires, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial sworn compliance report 90 days after the Order's effective date, and must submit sworn notices within 14 days of changes to contact information, organizational structure, or any bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain specified records for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, consumer feedback forms, and privacy-related representations.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor Respondent's compliance by requesting reports and records, communicating directly with Respondent, interviewing affiliated persons, and using other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and will terminate on August 15, 2036, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Participation in Privacy or Security Programs
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, in any manner, its membership in, adherence to, certification by, or participation in any privacy or security program sponsored by a government or self-regulatory organization, including APEC CBPR.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit its own acknowledgment of receipt of the Order, deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel and successors, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an initial sworn compliance report 60 days after the Order's issuance date, and thereafter submit sworn notices within 14 days of changes in contact information, corporate structure, or bankruptcy filings, following specified formatting and delivery requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for 20 years after the Order's issuance date and retain each record for 5 years, covering accounting, personnel, compliance, and marketing materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Respondent must cooperate with Commission monitoring by submitting additional compliance information and records upon request, permitting direct communications and voluntary interviews, and allowing the Commission to use all lawful investigative means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates on June 21, 2036, or 20 years from the most recent date a complaint alleging any Order violation is filed in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Participation in Privacy or Security Programs
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, in any manner, the extent to which it participates in, is certified by, or otherwise belongs to any privacy or security program sponsored by a government or self-regulatory organization, including the EU-U.S. and Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield frameworks.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must acknowledge receipt of this Order, deliver copies to relevant personnel and business entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments from all recipients.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an initial sworn compliance report 60 days after the issuance date and provide timely sworn notices of any changes in contact information, organizational structure, or bankruptcy proceedings.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for ten (10) years and retain each such record for five (5) years, covering personnel records, compliance documentation, and copies of advertising materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondent's compliance by requesting additional reports and records, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using undercover methods or compulsory process.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order becomes final and effective upon publication on the FTC's website and will terminate on August 12, 2039, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date the Commission or the United States files a complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from failing to provide Direct Notice, failing to post required privacy links, failing to obtain Verifiable Parental Consent or School Authorization, conditioning participation on excess data disclosure, retaining Children's Personal Information longer than necessary, and violating the COPPA Rule.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Using Schools to Provide Direct Notice to Parents or Obtain Verifiable Parental Consent
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from relying on Schools to obtain Verifiable Parental Consent on its behalf and from relying on School Authorization without a written agreement containing specific required elements.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Data Minimization Requirement
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from Collecting more Personal Information from Children than is reasonably necessary for the Child to participate in any activity offered on the Edmodo Platform.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Use of Previously Collected Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant must refrain from using previously collected Children's Personal Information without consent, destroy existing non-consented data within 60 days, provide sworn written statements to the Commission within 90 days, delete Affected Work Product within 90 days, and maintain a data retention schedule.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: A $6 million civil penalty judgment is entered against Defendant but suspended based on Defendant's sworn financial statements; the suspension will be lifted and the full amount become due if Defendant is found to have made material misstatements in its Financial Attestations.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from misrepresenting its privacy and security practices, compliance program memberships (including HIPAA and Privacy Shield), HIPAA regulatory status, and the independent status of endorsers or reviewers of its products.

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Defendant must establish, implement, and maintain for 20 years a comprehensive information security program protecting Personal Information and Customer Information, including documented policies, designated personnel, risk assessments, safeguards, and vendor oversight.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 7(a) of the Controlling the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography and Marketing Act of 2003 (CAN-SPAM Act), 15 U.S.C. § 7706(a)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Defendant must annually submit a sworn certification from a senior corporate manager or officer confirming compliance with the Order, the absence of uncorrected material noncompliance, and a description of all Covered Incidents during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 7(a) of the Controlling the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography and Marketing Act of 2003 (CAN-SPAM Act), 15 U.S.C. § 7706(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: For 20 years, Defendant must submit a report to the Commission within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident, including the date, description, affected information types, number of affected consumers, remediation steps taken, and copies of notices sent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 7(a) of the Controlling the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography and Marketing Act of 2003 (CAN-SPAM Act), 15 U.S.C. § 7706(a)

provisions.title: Prohibitions Concerning Commercial Email
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from violating Section 5 of the CAN-SPAM Act, including by sending commercial emails without a physical postal address or opt-out notice, and by failing to honor opt-out requests within 10 business days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 7(a) of the Controlling the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography and Marketing Act of 2003 (CAN-SPAM Act), 15 U.S.C. § 7706(a)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Judgment of $2,950,000 is entered against Defendant as a civil penalty, to be paid to the U.S. Treasury within 7 days of entry of this Order by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 7(a) of the Controlling the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography and Marketing Act of 2003 (CAN-SPAM Act), 15 U.S.C. § 7706(a)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations Regarding Online Collection of Personal Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must not make any misrepresentation in connection with online collection of personal information from children and/or consumers ages 13–17, including about anonymity, promised products/services, prize eligibility, or collection and use practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Collecting Personal Information Without Parental Permission
provisions.summary: Respondent must not collect personal information from a child at a website directed to children (or any site where respondent has actual knowledge it is collecting from a child) when respondent has actual knowledge the child lacks parental permission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Affirmative Obligation to Provide Clear and Prominent Privacy Notice
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide clear and prominent notice of its practices regarding collection and use of personal information from children, including what is collected, how it is used, disclosure practices, and a means for parents to access or delete their child's information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Affirmative Obligation to Obtain Verifiable Parental Consent
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain a procedure to obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting, using, or disclosing personal information from children online.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Deletion of Previously Collected Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must delete all personal information previously collected from children prior to the date of service of this order from its websites directed to children and any commercial websites where it has actual knowledge it collected personal information from a child.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: COPPA Compliance as Deemed Compliance
provisions.summary: After the effective date of COPPA and any FTC regulations or guides thereunder, compliance with that statute and its regulations shall be deemed compliance with the definitions section and Parts II, III, and IV of this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC upon request records evidencing compliance with Parts III–V, including copies of web pages and information collection forms, and all materials evidencing verifiable parental consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities — current personnel within 30 days, future personnel within 30 days of assuming their position.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under this order, including dissolution, sale, merger, bankruptcy, or name/address change.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 60 days of service of this order and at such other times as the FTC may require.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order terminates on August 12, 2019, or 20 years from the most recent date the United States or FTC files a federal court complaint alleging any violation of the order, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of consumers' personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program reasonably designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Permanent Injunction — COPPA Rule Compliance
provisions.summary: Defendants and all persons acting in concert with them are permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the COPPA Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312, as it may be amended.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Consumer Education — FTC Privacy Notice on Child-Directed Sites
provisions.summary: For five years, defendants must post a bold, conspicuous FTC privacy hyperlink in their privacy policy, parent notice, and at each personal-information collection point on any child-directed website or online service.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Consumer Education — OnGuardOnline Safety Tips on Blog Hosting Service
provisions.summary: For five years, defendants must place a conspicuous OnGuardOnline social-networking safety-tips hyperlink on the homepage(s) and privacy notice(s) of any blog hosting service they operate.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — $1,000,000
provisions.summary: Defendants must pay a $1,000,000 civil penalty jointly and severally: $600,000 within five business days of entry, then two $200,000 installments (plus interest) due at six and twelve months from entry.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Default in Payment
provisions.summary: If any payment is in default for ten days beyond its due date, the entire remaining unpaid penalty plus interest becomes immediately due and payable.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Deletion of Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Within five days of entry, defendants must delete all personal information collected and maintained in violation of the COPPA Rule through the date of entry.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Distribution of Order and Compliance Guide — Current Personnel
provisions.summary: Within thirty days of entry, defendants must provide a copy of the Consent Decree and COPPA compliance guide to all current principals, officers, directors, managers, relevant employees, agents, and representatives, obtain signed acknowledgments, and submit a compliance statement to the Commission within ten days thereafter.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Distribution of Order and Compliance Guide — Future Personnel
provisions.summary: For five years from entry, defendants must provide the Consent Decree and compliance guide to all future principals, officers, directors, managers, relevant employees, agents, and representatives within thirty days of their assuming such position, obtain signed and dated acknowledgments, and maintain those records for Commission inspection upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: For three years, individual defendants must notify the Commission of changes in address, employment, ownership, name, and corporate structure. Beginning sixty days after entry, all defendants must submit sworn written compliance reports whenever the FTC reasonably requires, detailing registration practices, privacy notices, parental consent procedures, and data protection measures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: For five years from entry, defendants must maintain and make available to the FTC (within fourteen days of a written request) print or electronic copies of all documents demonstrating compliance, including acknowledgments, reports, web page copies with URLs, and all materials related to the collection, use, and disclosure of children's personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Provision of Taxpayer Identifying Numbers
provisions.summary: Defendants must furnish their taxpayer identifying numbers (SSN or EIN) to the FTC pursuant to 31 U.S.C. § 7701 for use in collecting and reporting on any delinquent amounts owed to the government.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Continuing Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter to allow any party to seek further orders for interpretation, modification, enforcement, or punishment of violations of the Consent Decree.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Privacy Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it maintains and protects the privacy and confidentiality of covered information, or its participation in privacy or security compliance programs.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Comprehensive Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program reasonably designed to address privacy risks and protect the privacy and confidentiality of covered information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Third-Party Privacy Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial privacy assessments from a qualified, independent third-party professional covering the first 180 days and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC various records including privacy-related statements, consumer complaints, law enforcement communications, compliance documents, and assessment materials for periods of five years.

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on August 30, 2032, or twenty years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Collection of Personal Information from Children

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Consumer Control and Notice
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the options through which consumers can exercise control over data collection or the extent to which consumers will receive notice about data practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC various records related to compliance, representations, and consumer complaints for specified periods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Distribution
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to current and future personnel with relevant responsibilities and obtain signed acknowledgments for 10 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission at least 30 days prior to any corporate changes that may affect compliance obligations under this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file compliance reports with the Commission detailing compliance with this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on August 28, 2035, or 20 years from the most recent date the U.S. or FTC files a complaint alleging violation of the order, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting to U.S. consumers any aspect of their data practices, use of engager profiles, authenticity of user profiles, number of actual users, account deletion terms, third-party awards, or participation in privacy/security programs.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Mandated Data Security Program
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to their size, complexity, and the sensitivity of personal information collected.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment and Partial Suspension
provisions.summary: A judgment of $8,750,000 is entered against Defendants jointly and severally; $828,500 must be paid within 7 days of entry, with additional remittance from a Directors' and Officers' Trust upon its termination; the remainder is suspended subject to conditions regarding truthfulness of financial representations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendants relinquish all rights to transferred assets, the Complaint's facts are established as true for future proceedings, and money paid may be used by the Commission for equitable relief including consumer redress.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from withholding customer information needed for Commission redress administration and from disclosing or misusing personal information obtained prior to entry of this Order, except for current customers in compliance with Section I.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 7 days, deliver the Order to key personnel and new hires, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a sworn compliance report 1 year after entry, provide sworn notices of material changes within 14 days for 20 years, notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, and submit all required materials via specified channels.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create specified records for 20 years after entry of the Order and retain each record for 5 years, covering accounting, personnel, consumer complaints, compliance documentation, and marketing materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission has broad rights to monitor Defendants' compliance, including demanding reports and documents within 14 days, conducting depositions and discovery, communicating directly with Defendants and their personnel, and using undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security and Privacy
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they protect the privacy, confidentiality, security, or integrity of Personal Information, including representations about collection/use/sharing, consumer control, and security procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Mandated Data Security Program
provisions.summary: Corporate Respondent and any business Individual Respondent controls must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written Information Security Program designed to address security risks to Covered Devices and protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notice and Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Prior to collecting or disclosing any Covered Information, Respondents must clearly and conspicuously disclose the categories of information collected, identity of third-party recipients, and all purposes for collection/use/sharing, and must obtain the consumer's affirmative express consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Each Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the Commission within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel and new business entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit annual compliance reports and timely notices of material changes (including structural changes, personnel changes for Individual Respondent, and bankruptcy filings) to the Commission, all sworn under penalty of perjury.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain specified records for 20 years after issuance (retaining each for at least 5 years), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, representations about Personal Information, law enforcement communications, and assessment materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports and records, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent-affiliated persons, and using any other lawful means including undercover investigation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates and Duration
provisions.summary: The Order becomes final and effective upon publication on ftc.gov and terminates on September 6, 2038, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging any violation of this Order in federal court, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Designating Content on the YouTube Service as Directed to Children
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from failing to develop and maintain a system for Channel Owners to designate content as directed to Children, and from failing to provide annual COPPA training for personnel managing Channel Owner relationships.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from failing to provide direct notice to parents, failing to post a prominent privacy notice link, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent, and from violating the COPPA Rule, in connection with operating a Website or Online Service Directed to Children on the YouTube Service.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Use of Previously Collected Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendants must refrain from disclosing, using, or benefitting from Personal Information previously collected from users of Content designated as directed to Children, within 90 days of the Compliance Date, with an exception for government-required disclosures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty and Other Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Defendants are ordered to pay $136,000,000 to the FTC and $34,000,000 to the State of New York as civil penalties and damages, both within 30 days of entry of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendants relinquish all rights to transferred assets, agree that Complaint facts may be used in future proceedings, and must submit their Taxpayer Identification Numbers to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit sworn acknowledgments of receipt of the Order, deliver copies to key personnel, and obtain signed acknowledgments within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit an annual compliance report one year after the Compliance Date, timely notices of structural or contact changes for 10 years, bankruptcy notices within 14 days, and all sworn submissions must comply with specific formatting and delivery requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.summary: Defendants must create specified records for ten years after entry of the Order and retain each record for five years, covering accounting, personnel, compliance, consumer complaints, privacy forms, and advertising materials related to the YouTube Service.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)
