provisions.title: Order Delivery and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all relevant current and future personnel within specified timeframes and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under this order, such as dissolution, merger, sale, or bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial written compliance report with the FTC within 60 days of service of this order and additional reports within 10 days of written notice from the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Duration
provisions.summary: This order terminates on September 29, 2035, or twenty years from the most recent date the FTC files a federal court complaint alleging any violation of the order, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Participation in Privacy or Security Programs
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, expressly or by implication, the extent to which it participates in, is certified by, or complies with any government or self-regulatory privacy or security program, including the EU-U.S. and Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield frameworks.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent and associated persons must not misrepresent, expressly or by implication, the extent to which it monitors or audits internal access to consumers' Personal Information, or the extent to which it protects the privacy, confidentiality, security, or integrity of Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written privacy program reasonably designed to address privacy risks and protect Personal Information, including designated personnel, risk assessments, controls, service provider oversight, and ongoing program evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Privacy Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial third-party privacy assessments by a qualified, independent professional with at least 3 years of experience, approved by the FTC, covering the first 180 days and each 2-year period thereafter for 20 years, with each assessment completed within 60 days after the reporting period and provided to the Commission within 10 days of completion.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a report to the FTC within a reasonable time after discovering a Covered Incident, but no later than 10 days after first notifying any U.S. government entity, detailing the incident's date, facts, affected information types, number of consumers, remediation steps, and copies of consumer notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt within 10 days of the Order's effective date, deliver copies of the Order to principals, relevant employees, agents, and successor entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn annual compliance report one year after the Order's issuance and sworn notices within 14 days of changes in designated contacts, corporate structure, or bankruptcy filings; all submissions must be sworn under penalty of perjury and submitted via email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for 20 years after the Order's issuance date and retain each for 5 years (unless otherwise specified), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, privacy representations, assessment materials, bug bounty reports, law enforcement communications, and records contradicting compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor Respondent's compliance by requiring additional reports and records within 10 days of a written request, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover approaches.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates on October 25, 2038, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging any violation of the Order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Participation in or Compliance with Privacy Programs
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner its membership in, adherence to, compliance with, or participation in any government- or self-regulatory-sponsored privacy or security program, including the EU-U.S. Privacy Shield, Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield, and APEC Cross-Border Privacy Rules.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Requirement for Annual Outside Compliance Review
provisions.summary: While self-certified under Privacy Shield, Respondent must obtain an annual outside compliance review from an FTC-approved independent third-party assessor demonstrating that its Privacy Shield assertions are true and properly implemented; a signed verification statement must be available to the Commission upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Requirement to Meet Continuing Obligations Under Privacy Shield
provisions.summary: Upon any withdrawal or lapse in Privacy Shield certification, Respondent must affirm to the Department of Commerce within 30 days and annually thereafter that it will either continue applying Privacy Shield Principles, protect the information by another EU/Swiss-authorized means, or return or delete the information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner their collection, maintenance, use, deletion, or disclosure of Personal Information, or the extent to which they protect the privacy, security, availability, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide an annual CEO certification to the FTC confirming compliance with the Order and disclosing any uncorrected material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident, Respondents must submit a detailed report to the FTC including incident dates, causes, types of information affected, number of consumers impacted, remediation steps taken, and copies of notices sent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Loyalty Rewards Program Accounts Review
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide U.S. consumers a clear and conspicuous method to request review of their Loyalty Rewards Program account for unauthorized activity within the preceding 12 months, and restore points lost to unauthorized third-party activity.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Data Handling
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide a clear deletion request process for U.S. consumers within 180 days, maintain a data retention policy limiting retention to what is reasonably necessary, and disclose the purpose of data collection in their terms of use or privacy policy.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the FTC within 10 days, deliver copies to all relevant officers, directors, employees, and agents, and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn compliance report one year after issuance, provide compliance notices within 14 days of any designated contact or structural changes, notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filings within 14 days, and submit all filings via email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain specified records for 20 years after issuance (retaining each record for 5 years), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, privacy representations, third-party assessment materials, law enforcement communications, and all compliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC has the authority to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports and records within 10 days, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondents' affiliates, and using all other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from its issuance date, or 20 years from the most recent federal court complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning the Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from failing to provide parental notice, failing to post required privacy links, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent, failing to delete children's data upon parental request, retaining children's data longer than necessary, and violating the COPPA Rule.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. part 312

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Children's Personal Information Previously Collected
provisions.summary: Within 60 days of entry of the Order, Defendant must delete all Personal Information associated with Affected Users (unless verifiable parental consent was obtained) and provide a sworn written statement to the Commission detailing its compliance actions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. part 312

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment and Suspension
provisions.summary: A $500,000 civil penalty judgment is entered against Defendant but suspended based on Defendant's sworn financial representations; the suspension is lifted if Defendant made material misstatements, and Defendant must submit its TIN within 7 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. part 312

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt within 7 days, deliver copies of the Order to key personnel within 7 days and to future personnel before they assume responsibilities, and obtain signed acknowledgments from all recipients within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. part 312

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn annual compliance report, provide sworn notices within 14 days of material changes for 10 years, notify the Commission of bankruptcy filings within 14 days, ensure all sworn submissions comply with 28 U.S.C. § 1746, and submit all materials to the designated Commission address.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. part 312

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create specified records for 10 years after entry of the Order and retain each such record for 5 years, covering accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints related to privacy practices, and all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. part 312

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through requests for reports and documents, depositions, direct communication with Defendant's personnel, and other lawful investigative means including undercover contact.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. part 312

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. part 312

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they maintain and protect the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Covered Information, including misrepresentations about security measures, privacy choices, data collection/use/deletion practices, or third-party access.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide annual certifications from their CEO (or designated senior officer) confirming compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected material noncompliance, and describing all Covered Incidents affecting 100 or more consumers during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident affecting 500 or more consumers, Respondents must submit a report to the Commission detailing the incident's date, facts, affected information types, number of affected consumers, remediation actions taken, and copies of consumer notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit their own acknowledgment of receipt within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to current and future principals, officers, relevant employees, subsidiaries, and agents for 20 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit an initial sworn compliance report one year after issuance, provide sworn notices within 14 days of structural or contact changes or bankruptcy filings, and submit all required documents to the Commission via specified channels.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create certain records for 20 years after the issuance date and retain each for five years (unless otherwise specified), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, System Assessment materials, privacy/security representations, Assessor materials, law enforcement communications, and records of non-compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports, conducting depositions, obtaining records, communicating directly with Respondents, interviewing affiliated individuals, and using all other lawful means including undercover operations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Modification of Original Decision and Order
provisions.summary: This Decision and Order supersedes the Commission's prior 2010 Decision and Order in In re Rite Aid Corporation, C-4308.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is final and effective upon publication on ftc.gov and will terminate 20 years from the date of issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date the United States or Commission files a federal court complaint alleging a violation of this Order, whichever is later, with specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Injunction – COPPA Compliance Requirements
provisions.summary: Defendant and those acting in concert with him are permanently enjoined from failing to provide required privacy notices, direct parental notice, and verifiable parental consent, and from violating any other provision of the COPPA Rule.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition on Misrepresentations About Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant is enjoined from making any misrepresentation in any website or online service's privacy policy or elsewhere about the collection, use, disclosure, or deletion of children's personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Deletion of Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant must delete all personal information collected in violation of the Rule from April 21, 2000 through the date of Order entry, within five days of receiving notice of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Consumer Education Remedy – FTC Notice Posting
provisions.summary: For five years from the Order's entry date, Defendant must post a clear and conspicuous FTC consumer education notice linking to OnGuardOnline.gov within required privacy policies, direct parental notices, and at each location where personal information is collected.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a civil penalty of $100,000, of which all but $1,000 is suspended subject to conditions, including compliance with the Retention of Children's Online Privacy Professional and Right to Reopen provisions.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty Payment
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay the $1,000 non-suspended civil penalty within five days of receipt of notice of entry of the Order by wire transfer or certified cashier's check payable to the Treasurer of the United States.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty Terms – Relinquishment, Acknowledgment, and Default
provisions.summary: Defendant relinquishes all control over funds paid, agrees the facts in the complaint are true for future enforcement proceedings, acknowledges the penalty is not dischargeable in bankruptcy, and agrees the full penalty becomes immediately due upon default continuing more than ten days.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Retention of Children's Online Privacy Professional
provisions.summary: Defendant must retain a qualified independent third-party children's privacy professional to conduct annual assessments for five years, or alternatively maintain membership in a Commission-approved COPPA safe harbor program for five years.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Right to Reopen
provisions.summary: The Commission's agreement to this Order is premised on the truthfulness of Defendant's financial statements; if the Court determines Defendant made a material misrepresentation or failed to comply with the privacy professional retention requirements, the Court shall lift the suspension and reinstate the full $100,000 civil penalty.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission has broad authority to monitor Defendant's compliance, including through written requests, document production, depositions, facility inspections, undercover posing, and interviews of Defendant's personnel.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: For five years, Defendant must notify the Commission of changes to his residence, employment, business structure, and name, and must submit periodic written compliance reports sworn under penalty of perjury, and notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Record-Keeping Provisions
provisions.summary: For eight years from the Order's entry date, Defendant must create and retain records sufficient to demonstrate full compliance with this Order, including acknowledgment copies, compliance reports, and sample web pages and documents regarding collection practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For five years from the Order's entry date, Defendant must deliver copies of the Order to principals, managers, and relevant employees of any business he controls, and to principals and managers of any business where he engages in relevant conduct, and must obtain signed acknowledgments within thirty days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a truthful sworn statement to the Commission acknowledging receipt of this Order within five business days of receiving it.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty Payment
provisions.summary: Google must pay a civil penalty of $22.5 million to the United States.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(1) and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(1) and 56(a)

provisions.title: Cookie Deletion Systems
provisions.summary: Until February 15, 2014, Google must maintain systems that delete Google cookies from Safari browser users.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(1) and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(1) and 56(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Google must report to the FTC within twenty days after February 15, 2014, demonstrating compliance with the order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(1) and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(1) and 56(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently prohibited from making false or misleading representations about the extent to which they protect the security, privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information collected from consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. provisions.title: Prohibition Against Violating GLB Privacy Rule
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently prohibited from violating the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act Privacy Rule, including failing to provide privacy notices to consumers at the start of the relationship and annually thereafter.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. provisions.summary: Defendants must establish and maintain a comprehensive written information security program designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected from consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Defendants must obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments from qualified professionals for 20 years, certifying that their security program provides reasonable assurance of protection for personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. provisions.summary: Respondent must cooperate with FTC compliance monitoring by submitting additional reports and producing records within 10 days of written request, permitting direct communications and voluntary interviews, and allowing the FTC to use all lawful investigative means.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Information Practices
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner its information practices in connection with any covered online service, including what personal information is collected, how it is protected, how it is handled upon policy changes, and parental controls for children's information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to its size, complexity, and the sensitivity of the personal information it collects.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC for five years all documents relating to compliance, including advertising materials, Web pages, plans, reports, audits, and any documents that contradict or qualify its compliance with the order.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, and employees with managerial responsibilities related to the order's subject matter — within 30 days for current personnel and 30 days of assuming a position for future personnel.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change (dissolution, merger, sale, bankruptcy filing, name/address change, or creation/dissolution of a subsidiary or affiliate) that may affect compliance obligations under this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 60 days of service of the order, and at such other times as the FTC may require, detailing the manner and form in which it has complied.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: The order terminates on December 20, 2022, or twenty years from the most recent date the FTC or United States files a complaint in federal court alleging a violation, whichever is later, with specific exceptions for parts with shorter terms, non-defendant respondents, and complaints filed after termination.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Bond Requirements for Unsolicited Commercial E-mail
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from sending Unsolicited Commercial E-mail unless he first obtains a $1,000,000 performance bond, subject to specific terms regarding duration, surety, notice, and disclosure.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 108(c) of the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. § 1607(c); and Sections 505(a)(7) and 522(a) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLB Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6805(a)(7) & 6822(a)

provisions.title: Injunction Against TILA and Regulation Z Violations
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from violating TILA and/or Regulation Z in connection with any advertisement promoting consumer credit extensions, including advertising inaccurate credit terms, rates, payment rates, or repayment periods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 108(c) of the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. § 1607(c); and Sections 505(a)(7) and 522(a) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLB Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6805(a)(7) & 6822(a)

provisions.title: Injunction Against Violations of Subtitle A of Title V of the GLB Act
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from violating or assisting others in violating Subtitle A of Title V of the GLB Act or the Privacy Rule, including failing to provide required privacy/opt-out notices, improper disclosure of nonpublic personal information, and prohibited reuse or redisclosure of such information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 108(c) of the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. § 1607(c); and Sections 505(a)(7) and 522(a) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLB Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6805(a)(7) & 6822(a)

provisions.title: Injunction Against Violations of Subtitle B of Title V of the GLB Act
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from violating or assisting others in violating Subtitle B of Title V of the GLB Act, including obtaining or attempting to obtain customer information of a financial institution through false, fictitious, or fraudulent statements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 108(c) of the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. § 1607(c); and Sections 505(a)(7) and 522(a) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLB Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6805(a)(7) & 6822(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Personal Information Practices
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner how it handles personal information, including representations about selling or renting data to third parties, sharing children's data, notifying consumers of policy changes, or collecting and disclosing personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Prohibition on Disclosure of Pre-Policy-Change Personal Information Without Opt-In Consent
provisions.summary: Respondent must not disclose to any third party personal information collected on www.hop.com before June 20, 2003 (when the revised privacy policy permitting third-party sharing was posted), unless the affected consumers provide express affirmative opt-in consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Prohibition on Retroactive Application of Material Privacy Policy Changes Without Opt-In Consent
provisions.summary: Respondent must not apply material changes to its privacy policy to information previously collected from consumers without first obtaining those consumers' express affirmative opt-in consent.

provisions.title: Disgorgement Payment to U.S. Treasury
provisions.summary: Respondent must pay $4,608 to the United States Treasury as disgorgement within five days of service of this Order, by cashier's or certified check, with interest accruing on any unpaid balance after a ten-day default period.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC for five years all documents demonstrating compliance with this Order, including copies of privacy statements, opt-in consent records, and records of disclosures to third parties.

provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes

provisions.summary: This Order terminates on September 10, 2024, or twenty years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging any violation of the Order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.

provisions.title: Prohibition against Misrepresentations about Covered Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, expressly or by implication, the extent to which he protects the privacy and confidentiality of Covered Information, including how it is collected, used, shared, or sold, and the purposes for doing so.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Required Deletion of Data
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide a sworn written statement identifying all persons with whom GSRApp Covered Information was shared, delete or destroy all such Covered Information and derived work products, and confirm the deletion in a sworn statement to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the Commission, deliver copies to relevant personnel and business entities, and collect signed acknowledgments from each recipient.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn annual compliance report one year after issuance, provide sworn notices of any material changes within 14 days, and report any bankruptcy filing within 14 days; all submissions must meet specified format and delivery requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain specified business records for five years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, marketing materials, privacy-related representations, law enforcement communications, and all compliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission may monitor Respondent's compliance by requiring additional reports and records within 10 days of request, communicating directly with and interviewing affiliated persons, and using lawful investigative means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order becomes final upon publication on the FTC website and terminates twenty years from issuance, or twenty years from the most recent date the Commission files a federal court complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Covered Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, in any manner, the extent to which it protects the privacy and confidentiality of Covered Information, including misrepresentations about how it collects, uses, shares, or sells such information, or the purposes for doing so.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy or Security Program Participation
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, in any manner, whether it is a member of, adheres to, is certified by, or otherwise participates in any government or self-regulatory privacy or security program, including EU-U.S. Privacy Shield, Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield, and APEC Cross-Border Privacy Rules.

provisions.title: Requirement to Meet Continuing Obligations Under Privacy Shield
provisions.summary: Respondent must not retain personal information from EU residents obtained while participating in the EU-U.S. Privacy Shield framework unless it either affirms continued adherence to Privacy Shield principles (or an authorized alternative) with the Department of Commerce within 10 days, or returns or deletes the information within 10 days.

provisions.title: Duty to Protect Covered Information
provisions.summary: Respondent is permanently restrained and enjoined from disclosing, using, selling, or receiving any benefit from Covered Information or any information derived from Covered Information.

provisions.title: Access to Corporate Documents and Data
provisions.summary: Respondent must make all correspondence, financial data, documents, computer equipment, and electronically stored information available to the Commission for inventory and copying, must provide access credentials for any computer equipment or electronic data, and must notify the Commission before abandoning any corporate books or records.

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates and Duration
provisions.summary: The Order becomes final and effective 60 days after service and terminates on November 25, 2039, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging a violation of the Order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from collecting, using, and disclosing personal information from child-directed properties without verifiable parental consent, and from violating COPPA.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Injunction Prohibiting Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendant must not materially misrepresent consumers' opt-out abilities, data collection practices, COPPA compliance, or privacy protections.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Injunction Requiring Consent for Collection of Location Information
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from collecting location information through SDKs without confirming consumer has provided affirmative express consent and has not revoked it through device settings.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Defendant must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program that protects covered information collected through ad tech services.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Privacy Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain initial and biennial third-party privacy assessments for twenty years from qualified, independent assessors.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Privacy Assessor
provisions.summary: Defendant must provide assessors with all relevant information and materials, ensure network visibility, and not misrepresent material facts.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Defendant must provide annual certifications from senior management for ten years confirming compliance with the order and disclosing any material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: A judgment of $7,500,000 is entered against Defendant, with $2,000,000 to be paid within seven days and the remainder suspended subject to truthfulness of financial attestations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendant relinquishes rights to transferred assets and acknowledges complaint facts will be taken as true in future litigation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Data Deletion
provisions.summary: Defendant must delete all ad request data collected prior to entry of the order within ninety days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Notice to Demand-Side Partners
provisions.summary: Defendant must transmit notice to all demand-side partners within thirty days and certify completion within thirty-five days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain acknowledgments of receipt of order from itself, current and future personnel, and business entities resulting from structural changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit compliance reports and notices describing its businesses, compliance status, and any changes in structure or designated contacts.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain specific records for ten years after entry of order, with each record retained for five years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor compliance through document requests, depositions, interviews, and other lawful means.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent how they review data suppliers' consent frameworks, how they collect or handle Covered Information, or the extent to which their Location Data is deidentified.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibitions on the Use, Sale, or Disclosure of Sensitive Location Data
provisions.summary: Respondents must not sell, license, transfer, share, disclose, or use in any products or services Sensitive Location Data associated with identified Sensitive Locations, subject to limited exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Sensitive Location Data Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish and maintain a Sensitive Location Data Program within 90 days that develops a comprehensive list of Sensitive Locations and prevents the use, sale, or disclosure of Sensitive Location Data.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Other Location Data Obligations
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish policies and technical measures within 90 days to prevent association of Location Data with LGBTQ+ service locations, political demonstration locations, or use to identify individual home addresses, and must impose equivalent contractual restrictions on recipients.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Third-Party Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a report to the FTC within 30 days of determining that a Third-Party Incident has occurred, including details about the incident's nature, scope, affected consumers, and remediation steps.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Limitations on Collection, Use, Maintenance, and Disclosure of Location Data
provisions.summary: Respondents must not collect, use, maintain, or disclose Location Data from consumers who have opted out of tracking via mobile OS privacy settings, and within 90 days must not collect or use any Location Data without a documented record of consumer consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Supplier Assessment Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must implement a Supplier Assessment Program within 90 days to ensure consumers have consented to the collection and use of their precise location data, including documented assessments of all data suppliers and cessation of use of non-consented data.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Disclosures to Consumers
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide consumers with a clear and conspicuous means to request the identity of entities to whom their Location Data was sold or disclosed, or alternatively provide a mechanism for consumers to request deletion of their Location Data from all recipients' databases.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Withdrawing Consent
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide consumers with a simple, easily-located means to withdraw consent to Respondents' use or disclosure of their Location Data.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Obligations When Consent is Withdrawn
provisions.summary: Respondents must cease using and disclosing all Location Data associated with a specific device within 15 days after receiving notice that a consumer has withdrawn their consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Location Data Deletion Requests
provisions.summary: Respondents must implement a simple, clear means for consumers to request deletion of their Location Data and must complete such deletions within 30 days of receiving a request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Data Retention Limits
provisions.summary: Respondents must document, publish, and adhere to a publicly available retention schedule for Covered Information within 60 days, submit it to the Commission, and update the schedule before collecting new types of consumer information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Deletion
provisions.summary: Respondents must delete all Historic Location Data within 60 days and all Data Products within 90 days, notify customers who received Historic Location Data, and submit confirmations to the Commission, unless they can document valid consumer consent or deidentify the data.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program within 60 days that includes written documentation, board-level reporting, designated employee responsibility, annual risk assessments, safeguards implementation, employee training, and ongoing testing and adjustment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit sworn acknowledgments of receipt of the Order to the FTC within 10 days, deliver copies to all principals, relevant employees, and agents within 10 days (and to new personnel before they assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn compliance report one year after issuance, notify the Commission within 14 days of changes to contact information or corporate structure, notify the Commission within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing, and submit all required filings electronically to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain for 5 years specified records including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, law enforcement communications, representations about data practices, and records documenting compliance with key Order provisions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance by requiring additional reports and records within 14 days of request, conducting direct communications and interviews with Respondents' personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover investigations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website as a final order and terminates 20 years from issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the Order, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from failing to provide required direct notice to parents, failing to post required online notice of information practices regarding children, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting personal information from children, and from violating the COPPA Rule.
provisions.company_name: Disney Worldwide Services, Inc. and Disney Entertainment Operations LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Mandated Audience Designation Program
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish, implement, and maintain for ten years a program to review each of their YouTube videos to determine whether it is a Kids Video and, if so, designate it as Made for Kids, with specific minimum requirements for documentation, staffing, training, and annual assessment.
provisions.company_name: Disney Worldwide Services, Inc. and Disney Entertainment Operations LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Judgment is entered against Defendants for a $10,000,000 civil penalty, which must be paid to the U.S. Treasury within seven days of entry of the Order by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.company_name: Disney Worldwide Services, Inc. and Disney Entertainment Operations LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies to principals, officers, covered employees, and agents within 10 days (or before they assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.company_name: Disney Worldwide Services, Inc. and Disney Entertainment Operations LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit an initial sworn compliance report one year after entry, ongoing sworn notices within 14 days of any structural or contact changes for ten years, bankruptcy notices within 14 days of filing, and all submissions must comply with perjury-declaration requirements and be sent to the designated FTC address.
provisions.company_name: Disney Worldwide Services, Inc. and Disney Entertainment Operations LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create specified records for ten years after entry of the Order and retain each such record for five years, covering accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, and all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance.

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendants' compliance through information requests, depositions, document discovery, direct communications, employee interviews, and undercover methods, with Defendants required to respond within 14 days of written requests.
provisions.company_name: Disney Worldwide Services, Inc. and Disney Entertainment Operations LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.company_name: Disney Worldwide Services, Inc. and Disney Entertainment Operations LLC
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Prohibition on Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent its privacy or cybersecurity protections for student information, or misrepresent the timeframe in which it will notify impacted individuals and school districts of a data breach.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Deletion of Unnecessary Personal Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must delete Covered Information that is no longer necessary to provide the contracted services or upon customer request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Data Retention Schedule
provisions.summary: Respondent must publish and comply with a documented data retention schedule explaining the purposes for collecting personal information, the specific business needs for retaining it, and a timeframe for deletion.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Covered Incident Notification to FTC
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC whenever it notifies any U.S. federal, state, or local government entity of a data breach or unauthorized exposure of consumers' personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Distribution and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondent must distribute copies of the Order to officers, directors, and employees with relevant responsibilities and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file written compliance reports with the FTC within specified timeframes after the Order becomes final and upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain documents necessary to demonstrate compliance with the Order for a specified retention period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: FTC Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC retains the right to access Respondent's facilities, records, and personnel to monitor compliance with the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Duration
provisions.summary: The Order terminates ten years from the date of its issuance, subject to extension if a compliance violation complaint is filed.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act
